text:
Lithium Mining in North Carolina: A New Frontier for Sustainable Resource Development in 2025 and Beyond

The lithium mine NC landscape is undergoing a historic shift. As we stride into 2026, North Carolina‘s lithium mines are emerging as the cornerstone of a state and national transformation in clean energy, infrastructure, and sustainable resource development. In this era defined by critical mineral demand and supply chain security, the focus on responsible mining practices and environmental stewardship has never been more pronounced.

Lithium—the essential element powering electric vehicles (EVs), storage batteries, portable electronics, and grid-scale technologies—is now one of the most sought-after minerals globally. The emergence of new lithium mine projects in North Carolina doesn’t just offer state-level economic development, but also signals a fundamental, sustainable shift in how we approach mineral extraction, infrastructure, defense, and agriculture for a cleaner future.

Lithium Mine NC: Geological and Economic Potential

North Carolina is reestablishing itself as a critical player in the United States’ lithium economy. Notably, the Piedmont region, with its pegmatite formations and high-grade spodumene-containing deposits, leads the way. Recent exploration techniques have confirmed these deposits as among the highest quality nationwide, thus positioning the state as a vital supply chain node for clean energy technologies.

The economic implications of lithium mine NC projects are profound:

Creation of new jobs and opportunities for local communities

Stimulus for infrastructure improvements, especially in roads, power, and water systems

Direct support for the state’s manufacturing sectors, including battery assembly and EV production

Diversification of rural economies traditionally reliant on agriculture or forestry

This shift can buffer North Carolina’s rural areas from market volatility and provide resilience and growth in the face of evolving global clean mineral demands.

7 Sustainable Development Strategies: Transforming the Lithium Mine NC Sector in 2026

To truly realize sustainability within the lithium mine NC ecosystem, North Carolina and its stakeholders are embracing innovative, environmentally conscious development strategies. These approaches not only reduce negative impacts but also ensure the long-term health of the environment, society, and economy.

1. Water Stewardship and Recycling Systems

Water usage and contamination are among the most critical environmental challenges associated with mining operations. In 2026, cutting-edge closed-loop water systems and water recycling technologies are being deployed across lithium mine NC projects.

Enables up to 90% recycling of process water

Minimizes extraction from local water sources and reduces risk of river or groundwater contamination

Protects agricultural productivity in regions adjacent to mines

By adopting advanced water stewardship, North Carolina sets a high bar for sustainable mineral extraction.

2. Dry Stack Tailings and Land Preservation Initiatives

The conventional wet tailings storage can lead to long-term environmental hazards and land degradation. The dry stack tailings method—where dewatered mine waste is stacked and sealed—is increasingly prevalent at lithium mines in North Carolina.

Significantly reduces risk of leaks or failures compared to conventional dams

Preserves large areas of usable land for post-mining reforestation or agricultural use

Aligns with the state’s commitment to environmental protection and redevelopment

3. Renewable Energy Integration for Mining Operations

The integration of renewable energy—solar, wind, and even geothermal—into the power supply of lithium mine NC projects is transforming traditional mining’s carbon footprint.

On-site solar panels, battery systems, and grid interconnections eliminate reliance on fossil fuel-based power

Curbs carbon emissions, contributing to North Carolina’s clean energy goals

Demonstrates the state’s leadership in sustainable mineral production

4. Environmental Monitoring Through Advanced Satellite Technology

Monitoring environmental impacts in real-time is key to responsible resource extraction. Satellite platforms, like those offered by Farmonaut, provide high-resolution data for:

Tracking vegetation health, spotting soil and water changes, and mitigating risks before they escalate

Ensuring post-mining land reclamation is effective, with restoration of native forestry and agricultural land

Supporting regulatory compliance and transparent reporting for all stakeholders

Farmonaut makes affordable, near-real-time satellite monitoring accessible, strengthening the environmental credentials of North Carolina’s mines.

5. Blockchain-Based Traceability in Resource Supply Chains

As traceability becomes essential for ethically sourced minerals, blockchain-backed systems are being adopted for lithium mines in North Carolina. Blockchain ensures:

Transparent tracking of lithium from mine to market

Authentication that resources are responsibly extracted and processed

Compliance with global clean energy and defense regulations

Learn more about blockchain-backed traceability for mining and supply chains on our Product Traceability page.

6. Community Engagement and Local Agricultural Partnerships

Lithium mine NC projects are increasingly rooted in broad community engagement and strategic partnerships with local agriculture and forestry operations:

Collaboration on soil and water monitoring to safeguard farmland productivity

Educational programs, re-skilling, and employment opportunities for rural workforce

Agro-advisory solutions supporting sustainable agriculture alongside modern mining—discover more on our Crop Plantation and Forest Advisory portal.

These efforts foster mutual growth, diversification, and resilient rural economies in North Carolina.

7. Lifecycle Carbon Footprint Tracking and Emissions Reduction

To meet 2026’s clean energy goals, lithium mine NC operators prioritize lifecycle carbon footprint analysis and emissions reduction:

Real-time tracking of carbon output from extraction, transport, and production using platforms like Farmonaut’s carbon footprinting tools

Optimization of fleet vehicles and machinery for efficiency—more at our Fleet Management page

Alignment with state and national policies for net-zero operations by 2030

Learn about carbon footprinting for mining sustainability directly on Farmonaut’s dedicated sustainability page.

Comparative Sustainability Impact Table: Lithium Mine NC Strategies

Infrastructure, Supply Chain, and Workforce: The Backbone of Lithium Mine Development in North Carolina

The success of lithium mine NC initiatives is underpinned by robust infrastructure, agile supply chains, and an adaptive workforce.

Infrastructure Improvements

Expansion of roads, rail, and energy grids ensures efficient transport of minerals and inputs

Power distribution upgrades support both mine operations and local communities

Advanced water management systems preserve resources for both mining and agriculture

Supply Chain Integration

North Carolina is securing a place in the domestic electric vehicle and battery supply chain to reduce reliance on foreign sources

Traceability, enabled by blockchain, links lithium mine operations with clean energy technology manufacturing

State-level initiatives ensure mineral resources flow directly to advanced manufacturing hubs

Workforce Development

Specialized training programs and technical education offerings are preparing workers for evolving roles in mining, technology, logistics, and sustainability sectors.

Reskilling programs for former agricultural and manufacturing workers

Certification in advanced mining technologies, environmental compliance, and clean energy systems

Support for new local businesses focused on mining-related goods and services

To facilitate large-scale monitoring and reporting across workforce and infrastructure projects, learn more about Farmonaut’s large-scale farm and resource management tools.

Empowering Modern Mining with API and Technology

Mining operators, developers, and local governments can seamlessly integrate satellite, AI, and blockchain data into their own platforms and supply chain management tools. Leverage real-time insights, compliance monitoring, and intelligent automation with the Farmonaut API—explore documentation on our API page and Developer Docs.

Defense, National Security, and the Strategic Importance of Lithium Mine NC

The strategic importance of lithium mines in North Carolina extends far beyond vehicles and consumer batteries. As the critical mineral powering advanced military technologies, lithium is essential for:

Energy storage for mobile command units and communications systems

Powering tactical vehicles, aircraft, drones, and advanced defense electronics

Supporting infrastructure resilience amid evolving global security threats

Developing domestic lithium mine NC projects is thus vital for safeguarding state and national interests. By securing a local supply and supporting next-generation energy solutions for national defense, North Carolina positions itself as a linchpin of U.S. strategic and industrial resilience.

Farmonaut’s Role in Supporting Sustainable Lithium Mining in North Carolina

At Farmonaut, we are dedicated to empowering the future of sustainable lithium mining in North Carolina through technology:

Our satellite-based monitoring tracks environmental changes across mining, agriculture, and infrastructure

The Jeevn AI advisory system delivers real-time insights, risk analysis, and compliance assurance for operators and regulators

We make blockchain traceability and resource authentication affordable and transparent for the mining sector

Our platform facilitates carbon tracking, fleet management, and post-mining reclamation monitoring

By democratizing access to high-impact satellite insights, we support businesses, governments, and communities in making data-driven, sustainable decisions for a cleaner energy future.

Frequently Asked Questions: Lithium Mine NC

What is a Lithium Mine?

A lithium mine is an industrial site where lithium-containing minerals, such as spodumene, are extracted from the earth. In North Carolina, these operations are crucial for supplying raw materials needed for batteries, electric vehicles, and grid energy storage solutions.

Why Is North Carolina Considered Strategic for Lithium Mining?

North Carolina possesses some of the richest, high-quality spodumene-bearing pegmatite deposits in the United States. The region’s geological assets, combined with a skilled workforce and advanced infrastructure, position it as a major domestic supplier for clean technology and defense industries.

What Are the Main Environmental Considerations for Lithium Mine NC Projects?

The top challenges include water usage, land disturbance, waste management, and preservation of agricultural and forestry productivity. Innovative approaches—such as water recycling, dry stack tailings, and satellite-based monitoring—help mitigate these risks and promote sustainable development.

How Is North Carolina’s Lithium Industry Impacting Local Rural Communities?

Lithium mine NC initiatives create high-quality jobs, support local businesses, provide workforce training, and generate economic resilience in rural areas—diversifying communities traditionally reliant on agriculture and forestry.

How Do Blockchain and Traceability Boost Supply Chain Security?

Blockchain-enabled traceability authenticates the entire supply chain journey of lithium—from extraction to end-use in batteries or EVs. This transparency is essential for responsible sourcing, compliance, and consumer trust in an increasingly regulated global market.

What Role Do Satellite and AI Technologies Play in Mining Sustainability?

Advanced satellite and AI platforms provide real-time data on environmental impacts, compliance, resource efficiency, and land restoration. These tools support informed decisions, regulatory reporting, and sustainable mining practices.

Conclusion: Redefining North Carolina’s Resource Economy in 2026 and Beyond

The lithium mine NC transformation marks a defining moment in North Carolina’s history. As global demand for clean energy technologies accelerates, the region’s geological richness, technological innovation, and commitment to sustainability ensure it will continue as a model for responsible mineral resource development.

By implementing advanced water management, renewable energy, community-driven engagement, and sophisticated monitoring tools, lithium mining in North Carolina is shaping the future foundation for resilient, sustainable supply chains that support economic vitality, environmental health, and national security.

For stakeholders across infrastructure, agriculture, technology, and defense, these developments present an unprecedented opportunity—not just to benefit from this critical resource, but to set global standards in sustainable resource management.

text:
As the world accelerates its shift toward renewable energy and electric mobility, lithium has emerged as one of the most critical minerals in the global supply chain. Central to this transformation is Western Australia (WA), which continues to dominate the global lithium mining landscape. In 2025 and looking ahead to 2026, the state’s lithium mining industry not only underpins the global demand for lithium but exemplifies sustainable mineral extraction practices that balance economic growth with environmental stewardship.

In this comprehensive guide, we’ll explore how lithium mining WA is setting benchmarks for sustainable extraction, driving technological innovation, and powering the global energy transition—all while supporting social development and environmental priorities. We’ll compare these advances with trends in lithium mining US, providing key projections and technological insights leading up to 2026.

“Western Australia produces over 50% of the world’s lithium, fueling global EV and battery technology advancements.”

Why Lithium? The Critical Mineral Driving Energy Transformation

In the 2020s, no mineral has become as critical to the renewable energy economy as lithium. Its unique electrochemical properties make it essential for manufacturing rechargeable batteries used in everything from electric vehicles (EVs) to smartphones and large-scale energy storage. These batteries are the very backbone of our transition toward decarbonization of transportation and power sectors.

Electric Vehicles: By 2026, EVs worldwide are expected to account for nearly 40% of new vehicle sales, with lithium batteries powering this explosive growth.

Renewable Energy Storage: Large-scale solar and wind projects require dependable battery solutions, of which lithium-ion leads the charge due to its high energy density and durability.

Decarbonization Push: Global climate goals and carbon-neutral targets (Net Zero 2050) are accelerating demand for lithium, especially in energy-hungry regions such as the US and China.

Positioned at the heart of this transformation is Western Australia, boasting the world’s most prolific hard rock lithium deposits and top production volumes. The US, aiming to bolster domestic supply and reduce import reliance, is investing heavily in lithium mining innovation. The race for dominance in the global lithium supply chain is on.

Lithium Mining WA & Global Landscape: 2025–2026

Lithium Mining WA: Backbone of Global Supply

Western Australia (WA) is synonymous with large-scale, high-grade, and technologically advanced lithium mining. By 2026, WA will maintain its lead, producing more than half the world’s lithium from hard rock deposits—primarily from spodumene mines.

Greenbushes Mine: The Greenbushes region hosts the most prolific lithium mine globally, with operations continuously scaled to meet skyrocketing global needs.

WA’s Major Mines: Apart from Greenbushes, Pilbara and Mount Marion are key operations that power both the local and international lithium supply chain.

Key 2026 projections for WA:

Estimated output: ~150,000 tons of lithium carbonate equivalent (LCE).

Sustained investment in infrastructure, advanced processing technologies, and automation.

Commitment to sustainable practices—including water recycling and targeted land rehabilitation efforts.

Lithium Mining US: Rapid Growth and Sustainability

Lithium mining US is focused primarily in Nevada, North Carolina, and Arkansas—regions blessed with a mix of brine, clay, and hard rock lithium resources. The US is emphasizing sustainable extraction to meet domestic battery and EV production needs while reducing import dependency.

Nevada: Home to the iconic Silver Peak Mine and new projects like Thacker Pass, leveraging both brine and clay resources for lithium output.

North Carolina: Increases in hard rock mining and rapid exploration for expanding production capacity.

Projections: US lithium output is on track to more than double between 2024 and 2026—supported by technology, ESG frameworks, and federal incentives.

“By 2026, U.S. lithium demand is projected to rise by 500% due to the surge in electric vehicle production.”

Comparative Trends Table: Lithium Mining WA vs US States (2026 Projections)

This comparative table highlights how lithium mining WA is not only an output leader but also at the forefront of sustainable practices. Meanwhile, US states are rapidly innovating in direct extraction and water technologies to close the supply gap by 2026.

Major Trends Shaping Lithium Mining WA & US in 2026

Decarbonization & EV Surge – Electric vehicle production is the catalyst for exponential lithium demand worldwide, especially in the US and EU, with both regions setting ambitious green targets for 2030 and beyond.

Supply Chain Security – Recent geopolitical disruptions have made Resilient, Localized Supply Chains a top priority, driving new investment into both WA and emerging US projects.

Technological Advances – From AI-powered remote sensing to autonomous haul trucks, the sector is adopting technology to enhance resource management and reduce operational footprints.

Environmental Regulations – Water stewardship and habitat protection requirements are accelerating adoption of closed-loop and circular economy solutions in new projects on both continents.

Social License to Operate – Respectful engagement with Indigenous and local communities, including integration of transparent tracking tools, ensures sustainable development with shared local benefits.

The convergence of these trends is reshaping how lithium mining us and lithium mining wa operate in the 2026 global context.

Technology & Innovation in Lithium Mining WA (2026)

How Automation, AI, and Digital Platforms Are Revolutionizing Mining

Lithium mining WA in 2026 is characterized by substantial investments in advanced automation, satellite technology, AI-driven exploration, and digital platforms. These solutions transform extraction and processing, significantly improving operational efficiency and dramatically reducing emissions and waste.

Autonomous Drilling & Haulage: Next-gen autonomous trucks and drilling rigs navigate remote mines like Greenbushes, enhancing productivity and worker safety while shrinking carbon footprint.

Satellite-Based Monitoring: Digital platforms powered by remote sensing allow for precise resource management and early environmental warning, helping companies optimize rehabilitation and restoration of mined sites.

AI & Machine Learning: Artificial intelligence identifies optimal drilling locations and forecasts production trends, reducing exploration losses and environmental disruption.

Resource Traceability Using Blockchain: Transparent, blockchain-powered systems ensure that every step of the lithium supply chain is authenticated and auditable—from mine to battery manufacturing.

Enhance your supply chain authenticity with Farmonaut’s blockchain product traceability—find out how here.

Discover More: Video Insights on Mining & Satellite Technology

Sustainability & Environmental Management in Lithium Mining

With increased scrutiny on environmental impacts, both WA and US lithium operations have embraced innovative technologies and renewed stewardship for the ecosystems surrounding mined sites. Key sustainability advances in 2026 include:

Water Use Reduction: Lithium extraction has traditionally involved extensive water use—especially concerning in arid regions of Western Australia and Nevada. Companies are increasingly deploying closed-loop processing, onsite water recycling plants, and even solar-powered evaporation to decrease freshwater withdrawal.

Land Rehabilitation: New standards require mining companies to restore native vegetation and foster local biodiversity post-extraction, minimizing lasting habitat disruption.

Farmonaut’s satellite monitoring and AI systems enable companies to track fleet operations efficiently and monitor environmental rehabilitation remotely.

Emission Tracking & Carbon Footprinting: Real-time digital tools now monitor emissions from haul trucks, drills, and processing equipment, supporting carbon-neutral goals.

Assess and optimize your mining carbon footprint using Farmonaut’s carbon monitoring platform.

Recycling Initiatives: Both Australia and US leaders are integrating battery recycling into supply chains—reclaiming lithium, cobalt, and nickel and reducing waste.

Regulatory bodies and progressive operators in WA now require transparent environmental impact reporting and public disclosure, setting standards for the lithium mining worldwide.

Social Impact & Community Engagement

The social license to operate has become a cornerstone of lithium mining WA in 2026. Engagement with Indigenous communities and local stakeholders goes beyond minimal compliance—creating participatory partnerships that respect traditional land, knowledge, and cultural heritage.

Transparent Training & Employment: Mining companies actively promote local jobs, skills training, and capacity building, contributing to lasting economic growth in regional communities.

Sustainable Community Initiatives: Operators sponsor infrastructure development—clean water, schools, and digital literacy—amplifying social benefits beyond mining revenue.

Traceability & Oversight: Digital traceability, often powered by blockchain, allows governments and communities to follow the journey of lithium from mine to market, ensuring fairness and compliance.

Inclusion of Indigenous Knowledge: Environmental management incorporates traditional ecological strategies for land stewardship and wildlife protection, fostering balance between resource extraction and ecosystem integrity.

These best practices are now widely adopted across major lithium regions in Australia and increasingly throughout US projects.

Economic Impact, Vertical Integration, and Global Supply Chains

The lithium industry in both WA and the US has evolved rapidly—from raw mineral extraction to full-fledged value chains encompassing refining, battery manufacturing, and recycling. Let’s break down 2026’s economic drivers:

Local Battery Manufacturing: Increasingly, lithium is being processed and converted into battery-grade chemicals near the source, minimizing export of unprocessed ore and retaining more value domestically.

Supply Chain Resilience: Australia’s and the US’s focus on downstream integration reduces vulnerability to global trade disruptions or single-point failures.

Attracting Investment: Venture and government capital continues to flow into mining infrastructure, digital innovation, and ESG compliance—fueling growth and job creation in regional economies.

This consolidation positions Western Australia as a resilient global leader in both economic performance and sustainable practices by 2026.

Exploration, Resource Expansion, and the Sustainable Future

2026 brings a new wave of exploration in both lithium mining WA and the US. Companies deploy the latest geophysical and geochemical mapping, remote sensing, and AI modeling to unlock previously untapped deposits.

Satellite Mineral Exploration: Satellite and drone surveys quickly identify promising hard rock and brine lithium targets—vastly reducing time, cost, and environmental disruption compared to legacy methods.

Environmental Due Diligence: New project assessments now demand climate risk, biodiversity, and water stewardship analysis before approval.

The future of lithium mining is both smart and sustainable, powered by technology, innovation, and a sense of responsibility to people and planet.

As the backbone of the lithium supply chain, WA’s world-leading practices—from advanced automation and digital platforms to rigorous environmental and community commitments—set the gold standard as the global energy transition accelerates.

description:

text:
By Nichola Groom

Dec 10 (Reuters) – U.S. President Donald Trump’s freeze on approvals for major onshore wind and solar projects is leaving thousands of megawatts of clean power capacity in limbo at a time of soaring demand for electricity, a Reuters review of permitting data and interviews with industry officials shows.

Just one solar project has been approved on federal lands since Trump took office in January, and none have been permitted since July when Interior Secretary Doug Burgum ordered that all new decisions related to renewable energy projects require his personal sign-off.

That compares to 13 solar and two wind projects approved on public lands under former President Joe Biden.

Trump, who has called climate change a hoax, has promised to fast-track energy infrastructure to meet rising electricity demand from artificial intelligence ‍and data centers, declaring an “energy emergency” to keep the United States competitive. But that policy excludes wind and solar projects.

The bottleneck extends to renewable projects proposed on private and state lands too, because they often require federal permits for wildlife or water impacts or access roads, according to developers and government officials.

Reuters examined permitting databases maintained by the U.S. Department of the Interior and spoke with 10 industry representatives for this story.

Energy research firm Wood Mackenzie said it has identified 18 gigawatts of solar projects on federal lands that were canceled or are inactive due to limited development progress since the start of the year.

“It’s extremely detrimental to our industry because it just upsets the ability to deliver projects,” said Abigail Ross Hopper, president of the Solar Energy Industries Association, which estimates that more than 500 solar and storage projects are threatened by the freeze.

Last week, more than 100 solar companies penned a letter to Congressional leaders urging them to revoke the Interior Department policy, which they said amounted to a near moratorium on new permits.

“It is difficult to understand how these actions align with the President’s stated goals of unleashing American energy and ensuring energy affordability,” three Democratic senators, Michael Bennet, John Hickenlooper and Ben Ray Lujan, said in a letter to Burgum last month.

U.S. electricity demand is expected to increase 32% by 2030, with ‌data centers accounting for more than half that growth, according to an analysis by power sector consulting firm Grid Strategies.

An Interior Department spokesperson defended its approach, without confirming the details of the Reuters reporting. “The Department continues its ‌heightened oversight of wind and solar projects on public lands and waters to protect America’s national security and critical infrastructure,” the agency said in a statement.

The freeze of onshore projects has been happening quietly in the background of the administration’s very public assault on offshore wind, a nascent industry in the U.S. that has been hit with stop-work orders, funding cancellations and revoked approvals for fully-permitted facilities. A federal court ruled on Monday that the administration’s suspension of leases and permits for new wind projects was illegal.

Trump has repeatedly argued renewable energy sources like solar and wind are too expensive, receive unfair subsidies, and are less reliable than fossil fuels because they depend on the wind blowing or the sun shining.

Instead, the administration has moved aggressively to expand fossil fuel production, accelerating leasing for oil, gas and coal projects, and ordering a cut in permitting timelines for fossil energy projects and mines to no more than ​28 days.

“President Trump’s energy dominance agenda unleashes our abundant resources like oil and gas, positioning the United States to win the AI race while simultaneously lowering energy prices and increasing grid efficiency,” Taylor Rogers, a White House spokeswoman, said in an email.

CLOUDS OVER NEVADA

Nevada, with its sun-soaked deserts, has emerged as the epicenter of the permitting slowdown, with more than 33 gigawatts of solar and battery storage projects on or adjacent to federal lands in various stages of development, according to Republican Governor Joe Lombardo.

Lombardo warned in an August letter to Burgum that federal delays threaten supplies to NV Energy, the ‍state’s top power provider, and may hinder mining and data center expansions.

The solar projects named by Lombardo are being developed by divisions of NextEra Energy, Korea’s Hanwha and Japan’s SoftBank.

“Nevada ​remains committed to an all of the above energy strategy that includes responsible solar development,” Lombardo said in a statement to Reuters.

NextEra and SB Energy both declined to comment. Joo Yoon, the CEO of Hanwha development arm 174Power ​Global, said several of its projects are suffering from federal permitting delays, “and we are making every effort to resolve these matters in any way possible.”

An NV Energy spokesperson confirmed discussions with the Interior Department are ongoing but did not elaborate.

In October, two months after Lombardo sent his letter, the Bureau of Land ‍Management canceled the environmental review for Esmeralda 7, a proposed complex of seven solar farms spanning 62,000 acres near Tonopah, Nevada.

The agency said developers may reapply individually.

The stakes are high for communities like Boulder City, a Las Vegas satellite community, that relies on revenue from solar projects on city-owned land. Leases on existing projects generate $21 million a year, or nearly 40% of the city’s operating budget, according to city officials.

Two new developments – Hanwha’s Boulder Solar 3, and Scout Clean Energy’s Boulder Flats – would add another $3 million annually. But both projects are waiting for a final sign-off from the Bureau of Land Management because a transmission corridor is under federal jurisdiction.

“They do not communicate with us,” Brok Armantrout, Boulder City’s revenue contracts manager, said of the city’s inquiries to BLM staff. “Even though the field office is here in Las Vegas, they’ve given us email addresses promising updates. And crickets.”

Scout Clean Energy, a unit of Brookfield Asset Management, declined to comment.

FREEZING WIND

Delays are rippling across the west.

In California, power provider San Diego Community Power renegotiated a supply contract for the 400-megawatt solar-plus-battery Purple Sage Energy Center project in Nevada in May after delays pushed its timeline back by a year, ‍according to documents and video from an agency board meeting.

“There has been no movement or guidance from the Bureau of Land Management on review timelines,” SDCP’s director of power contracts, Kenny Key, told Reuters in a statement.

The project’s developer, Primergy, a division of private equity firm Quinbrook Infrastructure Partners, had no comment.

Federal authorities also missed permitting deadlines for EDF’s 300-megawatt Bonanza Solar, a Nevada project that has a contract to provide power to two Los Angeles-area cities, Pasadena and Azusa, according to a federal permitting website.

And in September, Idaho Power asked the state’s utility regulator to cancel a 300-megawatt, 35-year ‍contract with NextEra’s planned Jackalope wind project in Wyoming, citing federal permitting delays. A spokesperson declined to comment.

Wood Mackenzie has ‍said federal permitting hurdles, combined with tariffs, could lower its U.S. onshore wind installation forecast by 22% through 2029.

Other agencies have also stepped up scrutiny of permits for wind and solar facilities, including those on private ​lands.

The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, which issues permits to projects that impact streams or wetlands, announced in September it would prioritize projects that generate the most energy per acre to comply with Trump’s emergency ​declaration.

Sprawling wind and solar projects ⁠generate less power per acre than gas or nuclear plants, and have spawned criticism about aesthetics, threats to property values and the environment. But they are also faster and cheaper to build than ‌alternatives like natural gas or nuclear power plants, according to the investment bank Lazard, which conducts an annual analysis of the cost of generation technologies.

The Army Corps said it has about 37 pending applications for solar and wind projects and added that applying the new policies should not meaningfully delay permit reviews. A spokesperson did not say whether any permits had been approved this year.

In another sign of obstacles now facing wind and solar development, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service restricted access to an online planning tool that developers of all kinds can access to quickly determine if a project overlaps with threatened species, migratory birds or their habitats and evaluate a facility’s impacts.

A notice posted on the website states that “solar and wind projects are currently not eligible to utilize” the tool until they are reviewed by Interior officials.

A service spokesperson said the change would improve coordination and create a faster and more predictable process. The agency did not say whether it was currently issuing permits to wind and solar projects. It does not maintain a public permitting database.

Renewable energy project proponents are now left wondering how long planned facilities can survive the stonewalling.

“When is the next presidential election?” Armantrout said when asked how long Boulder City is planning for the stoppage to last. “I know that’s a flippant answer, but ⁠it all depends.”

(Reporting by Nichola Groom; editing by Richard Valdmanis and Claudia Parsons)

text:
Editor’s Note: The Nonprofit Spotlight is NowKalamazoo’s collaboration with area nonprofits, providing space for them to highlight important work that might not be known to Kalamazoo County at large. Know of a group that should be in the NowKalamazoo Nonprofit Spotlight? Submit a nomination here.

Nonprofit name

Kalamazoo Climate Crisis Coalition (KCCC)

Year formed

Our team formed in 2019 and we obtained 501(c)3 status in 2022

Mission & population served

Our mission is to mobilize collective action to achieve immediate and drastic reductions in greenhouse gas emissions and rapid adoption of renewable energy through a transition grounded in social, racial, economic, and environmental justice.

We are committed to the work of a better climate future for our community, specifically to address these inequities: high energy costs and increasingly chaotic weather mean many of our neighbors struggle to afford needed home repairs and rising utility bills, often leading to an “eat or heat” dilemma; historic inequities, like redlining and decades of socio-economic challenges have led to barriers in property ownership and value, education and employment; and the preservation and efficiency upgrades of under-resourced family homes, which is one of the most impactful ways to reduce CO2 emissions locally.

At the heart of our work is a deep understanding that climate solutions must put the needs of those most impacted first. We offer programs in partnership with organizations committed to collaborating with homeowners in historically underserved areas in Kalamazoo County, including: providing critical home repairs and energy-efficiency upgrades in partnership with skilled trades experts; resource navigation leverages additional state, utility, and other public dollars to bringing more than $1M to Kalamazoo homeowners to support efficiency upgrades; workforce development training in partnership with existing programs; education to ensure those most impacted by pollution and extreme weather events have access to tools and knowledge to take action; and outreach to the community at-large by offering a book club and listening circles to normalize talking about topics that are taboo in some spaces.

The federally funded $18.9M Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Community Change Grant (CCG) we were awarded in late 2024 was terminated earlier this year, along with recipients of other organizations across the country focusing on environmental justice. This funding represented a years-long strategic investment in our community. The loss has been devastating.

However, we remain steadfast in our commitment to addressing generations-deep inequities across Kalamazoo – one home at a time – by providing critical home repairs and energy-efficiency upgrades. Each situation is unique, and may include added insulation, replacement windows, and/or a new HVAC system, ultimately reducing homeowner utility costs, increasing comfort, and making homes more adaptable to extreme weather events. More efficiently functioning homes lead to a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. Every energy efficiency measure gets us closer to driving real, impactful emissions reductions of atmospheric CO2 on a community scale.

We aim to increase the labor force skilled in green trades by supporting capacity building for existing workforce development programs. Workforce training programs can provide career pathways that break cycles of economic instability and address widespread shortages of skilled laborers for high-demand, good-paying jobs essential for Michigan’s infrastructure and economic future.

Through outreach and education, we are assisting homeowners and contractors in navigating options for tax incentives and rebate programs. For the community at-large, we continue our six-years-running program, Climate Conversations (formerly Fridays for Future), with a variety of guest speakers on issues relating to climate change. The Climate Change Book Club, offered in partnership with Western Michigan University, meets virtually every month. Our Ardea Youth Climate Leaders (YCL) program just graduated the fifth cohort in August. This youth-led initiative empowers high school students to become informed, confident and effective advocates for climate action. We are pleased to offer periodic in-person and virtual Climate Cafés in collaboration with the Michigan Climate Action Network to provide spaces for deep listening and normalize the feelings we experience in this time of multiple cascading crises.

The robust cross-community collaborations that were formed in preparation for the EPA CCG award remain, and today we are at nine partnerships. We will continue to strengthen and expand on those as project needs arise.

Impact story

Despite the devastating loss of our $18.9M Community Change Grant, our staff, board and all-volunteer Coordinating Committee scaled back planned outcomes to reframe the work and keep going. We remain deeply committed to our environmental justice priorities, and continue to pursue raising the funds required to provide critical home repairs and energy efficient upgrades. Collaborating with homeowners and contractors to secure resources for tax incentives and rebate programs remains a critical part of our work, and we are pursuing grant funding to help with this navigation service .

Our all-volunteer team formed in 2019 to plan and participate in a day-long series of events in observance of a global climate strike. It feels important to call out a few of the many accomplishments we have achieved since then, including securing formal climate emergency declarations from five local municipalities, establishing over 40 affiliate members from faith, education, business and environmental organizations, launching numerous education offerings, and obtaining grant awards.

How NowKalamazoo readers can help

KCCC hosts a number of outreach and educational events, and we would love to meet you! Stop by our table at the Kalamazoo Farmers’ Market (we’re there many Saturdays), volunteer via the form on our website, attend a Climate Conversation (once/month, virtually) or join our monthly Climate Book Club or participate in a Climate Café. Starting this month, we’ll be hosting monthly community meetings with one of our partners, the Northside Alliance for Community Development (NACD). Details can be found on our newly redesigned website: www.kalamazoocrisis.org.

Donations help us do our work in the community. Online donations are gratefully accepted, and checks can be mailed to 340 East Michigan Avenue, Kalamazoo, MI, 49007.

We also invite the community to get involved in our in-person and online events. On Dec. 10, the Michigan Environmental Council will host a Kalamazoo Is Ours To Protect event at KCCC, focused on a growing concern for the federal funding cuts and regulatory rollbacks that threaten our environment and communities. On Dec. 11, we’re hosting a Safe & Healthy Homes event at the Northside Association for Community Development (NACD), and on Dec. 12, WMU Professor Dr. Paul Clements will speak on international reforms needed for the United States to take responsibility for its carbon pollution, with a focus on climate migrants, in KCCC’s Climate Conversation series.

Get in touch

Website: https://www.kalamazoocrisis.org/

Email: jjdoezema@kzooclimate.org

Phone: 269-352-1213

Contact: Jenny Doezema, Executive Director

— Information and photos provided by Jenny Doezema

name: Clean Energy
title: 'Smart policy' needed for UK to seize clean energy jobs - Solar Power Portal
description:
In October, energy secretary Ed Miliband announced the Clean Energy Jobs Plan, aiming to make the UK “the winner in the global clean energy jobs race”.
The report highlighted the importance of transitioning skills from traditional energy sectors into the burgeoning clean energy economy.
Great British Energy, the government’s state-backed renewable energy company, has been allocated £700 million for UK clean power manufacturing operations.
In its Clean Energy Jobs Plan, which was released after the committee report finished collecting evidence, the government announced unspecified funding for Local Net Zero Hubs to map clean energy skills and jobs with local authorities.
It also announced £2.5 million in funding across 2025-26 for regional programmes in Cheshire, Lincolnshire and Pembrokeshire to support clean energy jobs.
text:
The UK could gain between 135,000 and 725,000 jobs from the energy transition by 2030 with the right policy, planning and skills programmes, according to a new report from the government’s Energy Security and Net Zero committee.

The “Workforce planning to deliver clean, secure energy” report said that the UK’s energy transition will create “winners and losers” in the workforce, as energy sector businesses move their operations away from fossil fuels towards low-carbon technologies, but that there is scope for “smart policy and expenditure” to harness opportunity.

In October, energy secretary Ed Miliband announced the Clean Energy Jobs Plan, aiming to make the UK “the winner in the global clean energy jobs race”. The plan introduced a range of measures on employment, regional powers and workers’ rights, along with £1.2 billion per year to support skills development.

The report highlighted the importance of transitioning skills from traditional energy sectors into the burgeoning clean energy economy. It said that the government must “tackle barriers preventing existing energy sector workers transitioning successfully”. Most prominently, North Sea oil and gas workers have become an emblem of the energy transition’s impact on jobs. Trade union Unite recently called the government’s North Sea Future Plans for workers “tinkering around the edges”, which lacks a reliable skills transition.

The Energy Security and Net Zero committee’s report said “many of the skills of the existing energy, engineering and construction workforces are highly transferable”, and called on the government to expand Skills Passports and associated funding to enable skills transfers between sectors. It also called for “tangible workforce transition and support targets” and measures to “leverage UK manufacturing content requirements where possible”.

The government’s Clean Energy Industries Plan, published earlier this year, said that the solar PV and storage industries are “vital” to the country’s industrial transition, alongside frontier industries like wind, nuclear and carbon capture and storage. Great British Energy, the government’s state-backed renewable energy company, has been allocated £700 million for UK clean power manufacturing operations.

The UK may need to import “specific skills” from overseas in the short term to meet decarbonisation targets, the committee argued.

The report also called for greater power for devolved governments and measures to transition local workforces. “National workforce planning will need to be delivered beyond Whitehall,” it said, and said delivering workforce change may look different in different local circumstances. It said that these differences should be considered “while providing both a consistent quality in career pathways, standards and training and a portability of skills across the UK’s nations.”

Statistics from big-four consultancy PwC showed that Scotland led the UK in clean energy jobs as of November 2024.

In its Clean Energy Jobs Plan, which was released after the committee report finished collecting evidence, the government announced unspecified funding for Local Net Zero Hubs to map clean energy skills and jobs with local authorities. It also announced £2.5 million in funding across 2025-26 for regional programmes in Cheshire, Lincolnshire and Pembrokeshire to support clean energy jobs.

name: Texas Environment
title: Greenpeace Scrutinizes the Environmental Record of the Company That Sued the Group
description:
Now the organization is calling attention to the environmental impacts of the pipeline company that brought it to court and won a $345 million judgment.
Greenpeace’s report on Dallas-based Energy Transfer summarizes public information on the company’s environmental record and calls for defending the rights to protest and free speech.
“This is what Greenpeace was built for.” Energy Transfer denies that the lawsuit aimed to stifle free speech.
Earlier this year a North Dakota jury found Greenpeace liable to pay $667 million in damages to Energy Transfer.
Energy Transfer reported releasing 18,312 pounds of nitrous oxides and 383,214 pounds of volatile organic compounds.
text:
The environmental nonprofit Greenpeace was under the microscope in a North Dakota trial this year. Now the organization is calling attention to the environmental impacts of the pipeline company that brought it to court and won a $345 million judgment.

A new report released Wednesday identifies oil spills, gas releases, air pollution and other incidents at Energy Transfer’s web of pipelines and infrastructure nationwide, including subsidiaries and joint ventures. More incidents occurred in Texas, where Energy Transfer is headquartered, than any other state, according to the report.

The report, titled Bad Neighbor, follows a March 2025 jury verdict that found Greenpeace USA liable for damages during protests against Energy Transfer’s Dakota Access pipeline. Greenpeace calls the case a strategic lawsuit against public participation, or SLAPP, designed to silence criticism of the company. Greenpeace’s report on Dallas-based Energy Transfer summarizes public information on the company’s environmental record and calls for defending the rights to protest and free speech.

“Greenpeace’s bread and butter has always been exposing and bearing witness to air pollution, water pollution, the climate catastrophe, and the impacts on people and ecosystems,” said Tim Donaghy, the report’s author and Greenpeace USA’s research director. “This is what Greenpeace was built for.”

Energy Transfer denies that the lawsuit aimed to stifle free speech. In a statement, the company called the guilty verdict “a win for all the law-abiding Americans who understand the difference between the right to free speech and breaking the law.”

In its report, Greenpeace referenced what it called four “major disasters” associated with Energy Transfer and its affiliates since September 2024, including two in Texas and one offshore in the Gulf of Mexico. Greenpeace also reported that of the 300 spills on pipelines owned by Energy Transfer and its affiliates between 2018 and 2025, almost two thirds occurred in Texas. The report said that Energy Transfer’s vast network of infrastructure in the Permian Basin is emitting millions of metric tons of greenhouse gases a year.

The report does not attempt to compare Energy Transfer to other companies, but shows the wide impact of one company that holds a large market share. Energy Transfer transports approximately 30 percent of U.S. natural gas and 40 percent of U.S. crude oil production.

Energy Transfer has been fined more than $100 million by federal, state and local regulators over the last three decades, according to the report. Greenpeace argues this is a “cost of doing business” for a company that in 2024 reported annual revenue of $80 billion.

“There is something wrong with a system that lets polluters off the hook but penalizes those who oppose them,” the report said.

“We are aware of the report, which recycles publicly available information in an attempt by Greenpeace to manufacture headlines,” Energy Transfer responded in a statement. “Furthermore, to intentionally misrepresent the data, the report falsely attributes to Energy Transfer issues with pipelines in which we hold only passive ownership, and which are operated by other companies.”

In the report, Greenpeace explains its methodology in detail. The report includes pipeline incidents from joint ventures where Energy Transfer is not the pipeline operator, but the company holds a greater than 25 percent interest. Greenpeace also included incidents for subsidiaries where Energy Transfer is the pipeline operator.

“Energy Transfer has a complex corporate structure that has changed significantly over time,” the report states. “The latest 10-K for FY 2024 lists over 400 named subsidiaries and several joint ventures. This makes the compilation and interpretation of past events complicated.”

Greenpeace on the Offense

Energy Transfer brought its suit against Greenpeace in 2017, alleging the organization defamed the company while supporting protesters who damaged property. Earlier this year a North Dakota jury found Greenpeace liable to pay $667 million in damages to Energy Transfer. In October, a judge cut that amount to about $345 million.

Post-trial motions are ongoing. Greenpeace spokesperson Madison Carter said the nonprofit plans to ask for a new trial if the court issues a final judgement that does not satisfy the organization. If that fails, Greenpeace can appeal to the North Dakota Supreme Court.

Greenpeace USA’s Donaghy said that the lawsuit goes beyond the defendants.

“If people don’t feel free to speak out against those who are polluting their air and water, and whose business model is driving us towards climate collapse, then what chance do we really have in enacting solutions to these problems?” he said.

Greenpeace said it compiled the report using public databases and records, which lawyers and fact checkers reviewed. It was also shared with Energy Transfer before publication.

This story is funded by readers like you.

Our nonprofit newsroom provides award-winning climate coverage free of charge and advertising. We rely on donations from readers like you to keep going. Please donate now to support our work.

Donate Now

Energy Transfer is primarily a pipeline company, transporting oil and natural gas from areas of production to facilities where it is processed and refined. The company has also expanded into the liquified natural gas industry and has extensive offshore operations in the Gulf of Mexico. Greenpeace said it relied on Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration (PHMSA) data to compile liquid spills and releases of hazardous gas.

Between Jan. 1, 2018, and June 30, 2025, Energy Transfer and its affiliates, joint ventures and subsidiaries, including Sunoco, reported 300 spills of hazardous liquids, or one every nine days, according to the report. Nearly 250 of those spills involved oil, totalling 31,860 barrels, or 1.34 million gallons.

“Fossil fuels are inherently polluting and it does seem that oil spills are continuously happening,” said Donaghy. “If you look at the data collected by PHMSA and across the industry, there’s just a drumbeat of small spills and large spills over time.”

During the same time period from 2018 to 2025, Energy Transfer and its affiliates reported 126 natural gas releases, according to PHMSA data cited in the report. More than 5,000 million cubic feet (MMcf) of gas were released in these incidents.

In Energy Transfer’s 2024 Corporate Responsibility report, the company said the total number of hazardous liquid accidents off its property decreased 21 percent from 2023 and were down 31 percent from the five-year average.

The largest gas releases occurred on the offshore Sea Robin gas pipeline in the Gulf of Mexico in two incidents in January 2025 and a third in May 2025, according to the report. The three leaks released a total of more than 3,000 MMcf of gas. All three incidents are among the five biggest gas releases reported to PHMSA by any company since 2010, according to the report.

An explosion at Energy Transfer’s Justice pipeline in Deer Park, Texas, on Sep. 16, 2024, was the largest release of hazardous liquids that Energy Transfer has reported to PHMSA since 2018, federal records show. More than 38,793 barrels of highly volatile liquids, which include natural gas liquids, were released.

The explosion occurred when a car slammed into a pipeline valve in the Houston suburb. The vehicle was engulfed in flames and the driver died on the scene. The death was later ruled a suicide.

Four people were injured and five homes were damaged, according to local news reports. A shelter-in-place order covered more than 1,000 nearby homes, businesses and schools.

Months later, the Railroad Commission of Texas, the state’s oil and gas regulator, reported that it had found no safety violations at the pipeline and would not issue fines.

The fire burned for more than three days as the pipeline depressurized. Energy Transfer reported releasing 18,312 pounds of nitrous oxides and 383,214 pounds of volatile organic compounds.

Air Alliance Houston, a nonprofit focused on the health impacts of air pollution, called for a better accounting of the incident and improved communication with local communities.

“There is a risk that comes with having pipelines in densely populated areas,” Inyang Uwak, the organization’s research and policy director, told Inside Climate News. “There can be fires and explosions that result in air pollution and chemical exposure.”

Uwak, an epidemiologist, added: “Pipelines are often considered a low-risk method of transporting hazardous compounds. However, accidents do happen, and we need to proactively prevent these accidents, particularly with above-ground pipelines.”

Energy Transfer added new concrete barricades around the pipeline valve site after the incident, according to Railroad Commission documents.

Katherine Culbert, a process safety engineer in Houston, said it raised a “red flag” that the Railroad Commission said it found no safety violations after investigating. Culbert is running for the Republican nomination for a seat on the Railroad Commission.

“I have worked for pipeline companies,” she said. “Every company has something where they could improve. If people are dying, there is something that could be done to make it better.”

Railroad Commission spokesperson Bryce Dubee said that less than half of 1 percent of reported hazardous liquid incidents were caused by vehicle damage. “Whatever the cause is, we thoroughly investigate each incident,” he said.

Energy Transfer’s largest crude oil spill since 2018 occurred on May 5, 2025, in Arlington, Texas, according to the Greenpeace report. The spill released a reported 6,600 barrels, or 277,200 gallons, of oil underground. The oil entered a broken sewer pipe and flowed to Fort Worth’s Village Creek wastewater treatment plant a few miles away. Oil appeared in several areas of the treatment plant and a popular birding area was closed. Cleanup costs were estimated at $5 million.

The report goes on to document greenhouse gas emissions from Energy Transfer’s operations in the Permian Basin, worker safety violations and other lawsuits that the company has brought challenging the constitutionality of pipeline safety enforcement.

“We’re not able to say if Energy Transfer is worse or best [among pipeline companies],” said Greenpeace’s Donaghy. “But we can say that their operations are causing impacts for communities, and that makes them a bad neighbor.”

name: EVs
title: Tesla Pushes Incentives to Lift Model Y Sales - Yahoo Finance UK
description:
Tesla (TSLA, Financials) is pulling out familiar and some new tools to spark interest in the Model Y as the year winds down.
Buyers considering the Model 3 can also get financing at 2.99% APR, a significant drop from typical rates.
Still, the incentives gave the stock a lift, with shares rising nearly 2.5% on Tuesday as investors welcomed signs that Tesla is working to protect delivery volume.
Ford has also stepped up its efforts, calling the current period a fight for survival in the EV market.
How far these incentives go and what they signal about underlying demand will be clearer once Tesla reports its next set of results.
text:
This article first appeared on GuruFocus.

Tesla (TSLA, Financials) is pulling out familiar and some new tools to spark interest in the Model Y as the year winds down. With only a few weeks left in 2024, the company is offering 0% APR financing for up to six years, along with free color and interior upgrades that normally add $1,000 to $2,500 to the price. Buyers considering the Model 3 can also get financing at 2.99% APR, a significant drop from typical rates.

Is TSLA fairly valued? Test your thesis with our free DCF calculator.

The push comes at a moment when the loss of federal tax credits has made electric vehicles less affordable for many shoppers. Still, the incentives gave the stock a lift, with shares rising nearly 2.5% on Tuesday as investors welcomed signs that Tesla is working to protect delivery volume.

Even so, the broader landscape remains challenging. In Europe, Stellantis is teaming up with ride-hailing company Bolt to introduce driverless vehicles to a massive customer base a move that could crowd Tesla's position in autonomous driving. Ford has also stepped up its efforts, calling the current period a fight for survival in the EV market.

How far these incentives go and what they signal about underlying demand will be clearer once Tesla reports its next set of results.

title: LCV Action Fund Endorses Mark Warner for U.S. Senate - League of Conservation Voters
description:
Washington D.C. – Today the League of Conservation Voters (LCV) Action Fund, which works to elect candidates who will fight to lower energy costs, build a clean energy economy, and strengthen our democracy for all, announced the endorsement of Mark Warner for re-election to the U.S. Senate representing Virginia.
I’m proud of my work negotiating the bipartisan infrastructure law and enacting the Inflation Reduction Act, both of which are delivering cleaner, more affordable energy,” said Senator Mark Warner.
Senator Warner has earned a lifetime score of 92% on the LCV’s National Environmental Scorecard.
About LCV Action Fund The League of Conservation Voters (LCV) Action Fund, the connected federal political action committee (PAC) of the League of Conservation Voters, works to elect leaders who stand up for a clean, healthy environment and to defeat anti-environment candidates who oppose climate action.
Over the last several years, our efforts have also helped elevate climate change and clean energy as critical issues in key elections.
text:
Washington D.C. – Today the League of Conservation Voters (LCV) Action Fund, which works to elect candidates who will fight to lower energy costs, build a clean energy economy, and strengthen our democracy for all, announced the endorsement of Mark Warner for re-election to the U.S. Senate representing Virginia.

“Senator Mark Warner is fighting for a clean energy future and to protect the health and safety of our communities, while the Trump administration continues their attacks on our environment, government institutions and clean energy, raising utility costs for families,” said LCV Action Fund Senior Vice President of Government Affairs Tiernan Sittenfeld. “It has never been more critical for members of Congress to stand up for our democracy, our rights, and our climate, and LCVAF is all in to support Senator Warner for re-election.”

“I’m honored to earn the endorsement of the LCV Action Fund. I’m proud of my work negotiating the bipartisan infrastructure law and enacting the Inflation Reduction Act, both of which are delivering cleaner, more affordable energy,” said Senator Mark Warner. “At a time when our country urgently needs more electricity, the Trump administration’s decision to cancel projects funded by these laws is driving costs up for families. I’m committed to working with partners like LCVAF to hold this administration accountable and repair the damage being done to our energy future and our environment.”

About Mark Warner

Senator Mark Warner has supported the expansion of clean energy technologies and, as governor, introduced legislation that would have provided grants that would have rewarded states that produced the largest gains in energy efficiency. He has served as a board member of Alliance to Save Energy, which is promoting new ways to make our current energy usage more efficient, and has co-sponsored legislation to provide incentives to help homeowners make their houses more energy efficient. Warner firmly believes that we need to reduce our dependence on foreign oil while investing in new technologies that reduce harmful emissions that contribute to climate change, and investment in research that focuses on green technology so we can continue to use our domestic resources more responsibly. Additionally, with Senator Kaine, he also introduced the Chesapeake Bay Accountability and Recovery Act to bring increased accountability and more collaborative management to efforts to restore the Bay. Senator Warner has earned a lifetime score of 92% on the LCV’s National Environmental Scorecard.

About LCV Action Fund

The League of Conservation Voters (LCV) Action Fund, the connected federal political action committee (PAC) of the League of Conservation Voters, works to elect leaders who stand up for a clean, healthy environment and to defeat anti-environment candidates who oppose climate action. Since the 1990 election cycle, LCVAF has helped elect and re-elect 101 U.S. Senators and 513 members of the U.S. House of Representatives. Over the last several years, our efforts have also helped elevate climate change and clean energy as critical issues in key elections.

name: Clean Energy
title: Grids are crucial to make Europe more competitive and energy secure - WindEurope
description:
10 December 2025 The European Commission has unveiled an EU Grids Package, a set of legislative and policy measures to modernise and expand Europe’s electricity grids.
Today the European Commission presented an EU Grids Package.
WindEurope’s latest study shows that a renewables-based energy system will save Europe up to €1.6tn, as compared to four alternative energy system scenarios, even when you factor in grids and system integration costs.
A renewables-based energy system will be much cheaper for Europe – even when you factor in the additional costs for grids, storage, and electrification.
What it means for wind Today wind energy is 20% of all electricity consumed in Europe.
text:
10 December 2025

The European Commission has unveiled an EU Grids Package, a set of legislative and policy measures to modernise and expand Europe’s electricity grids. The Package is a crucial step to make energy more affordable and secure for households and industry. It addresses long-standing bottlenecks in grid development. It proposes new rules for grid planning and permitting. And it sets out a vision for a more integrated, resilient, and future-proof energy system – based on high shares of wind.

Today the European Commission presented an EU Grids Package. It aims to boost investment in Europe’s grid infrastructure, strengthen interconnectivity, and support the EU’s energy security and competitiveness goals.

Grids are the biggest bottleneck to new wind energy projects. Europe needs to invest €584bn by 2030 to upgrade its grid infrastructure. But grid investment has long fallen short.

This underinvestment leads to curtailed renewable electricity and higher energy bills. It undermines Europe’s energy security. WindEurope’s latest study shows that a renewables-based energy system will save Europe up to €1.6tn, as compared to four alternative energy system scenarios, even when you factor in grids and system integration costs.

“Grids are vital to Europe’s energy security and competitiveness. A renewables-based energy system will be much cheaper for Europe – even when you factor in the additional costs for grids, storage, and electrification. But you can’t have more renewable electricity without more grids. The EU Grids Package will enable faster permitting, better planning and increased investment certainty”, says Giles Dickson, WindEurope CEO.

What it means for wind

Today wind energy is 20% of all electricity consumed in Europe. It will be 34% by 2030 and more than 50% by 2050. But Europe is not building enough new wind. Around 500 GW of wind energy projects are currently waiting for grid connection permits. The system is clogged up; authorities are overloaded.

To resolve this issue, the EU Grids Package recommends a shift from today’s “first come, first serve” principle to “first ready, first serve”, including new filtering criteria and project milestones. This new approach will help prioritise viable projects and filter out speculative “zombie projects”. This increases the visibility for permitting authorities and allows viable projects to move forward faster.

“We have entered a new age of electricity”, Executive Vice President Teresa Ribera explained, presenting the Package. Europe is set to ramp up the share of electricity in its total energy consumption, from below 25% today to 50% by 2040. This requires a totally different approach to grid planning.

The Package proposes better top-down grid planning. The Commission will take on a bigger role: it will create a forward-looking scenario for Europe’s Ten-Year Development Plan (TYNDP), in line with the EU’s 2040 and 2050 objectives. Europe’s transmission system operators will then base their planning on this new scenario. A new “infrastructure needs identification report”, drafted by ENTSO-E will identify present and future gaps and investment needs.

The Package will ensure grid investments mobilise both public and private finance. On the public side, the EU is scaling up its support for energy infrastructure in the next EU budget, including with a 5-fold increase in the Connecting Europe Facility. On the private side, the EU will launch a new Clean Energy Investment Strategy in 2026. It will propose concrete private sector actions, including from institutional investors, as well as support from the European Investment Bank (EIB).

The Package also aims to scale up Europe’s grid equipment supply chain. It proposes the establishment of a new platform for EU distribution network planning to track distribution grid related-manufacturing needs. Next year’s revision of the Public Procurement Directives will further strengthen Europe’s manufacturing base for grids technologies “made in Europe”.

Finally, the Package recognises offshore grids as a new priority. It contains new initiatives and rules around cross-border grid planning and cost-sharing. Next to that, the Package proposes new “Energy Highways”, key grid projects, such as cross-border interconnectors and offshore hubs.

Accelerating permitting

The Package tables a permitting acceleration directive which will involve tweaking various directives, including the Renewable Energy Directive (RED) and the Electricity Market Design Directive (EMD). The targeted Commission proposal contains important improvements, for example on the permitting of repowered wind farms, storage units and hybrid power plants.

“The Grids Package proposes a targeted and well-balanced revision of existing permitting rules. Good. But well-intended attempts to accelerate permitting must not end up undermining investment security. And they must not undermine public acceptance either. Stick to the sensible and targeted measures proposed by the Commission. And otherwise focus on implementing the Renewables Directive rules that are not being tweaked,” says Giles Dickson.

The Package includes further improvements to permitting, such as the option to introduce “positive silence” to speed up permitting decisions, a toolbox for public inclusion, and the application of “overriding public interest” to Projects of Common Interest (PCIs).

The Package asks Member States to establish a single digital portal at national level for all the steps of the permitting procedures for renewable energy, storage and grid projects. All document submissions and communication between project developers and authorities would take place on the portal. This marks a breakthrough in the digitalisation of permitting and could make paper-based applications obsolete.

Next steps

Electricity grids are the backbone of our energy system. They connect countries and allow electricity to be transported to where it is needed. The EU Grids Package sets out a clear vision for a modern, integrated, and resilient grid infrastructure that can deliver on the EU’s energy security and competitiveness goals.

Many elements of the Grids Package come in the form of recommendations to Member States. National implementation will be crucial. WindEurope stands ready to work with EU Member States and industry partners to make Europe’s grids fit for a future energy system based on high shares of wind energy.

name: Indiana and Evs
title: Europe's EV sector warns about 'efforts to dilute' EU emissions targets | 104.1 WIKY
description:
“We are deeply concerned about recent efforts to dilute your objectives,” the letter said, referring to intense lobbying efforts by the wider auto industry.
The groups added ‍that reopening the door to transitional technologies such as plug-in hybrids and CO2-neutral fuels would create uncertainty ‍and slow ‍the shift to electric vehicles, even ​as Chinese electric automakers streak ahead ​and ⁠cut costs.
“Every delay in Europe only ‌widens the gap with China,” it added.
The EU’s automotive package has been subject to intense lobbying, with letters from both industry and campaigners flooding Brussels ahead of the announcement.
(Reporting by Marie Mannes; Editing by ⁠Jan Harvey)
text:
By Marie Mannes

STOCKHOLM, Dec 10 (Reuters) – Leaders from across Europe’s electric car industry on Wednesday urged the European Commission to stick ‍to its 2035 zero-emission target for new cars, warning that any retreat would undermine investment and widen the bloc’s gap with China.

The EU executive is set to unveil an automotive package on December ‌16 that could give more flexibility ‌on CO2 targets and ease an effective ban on new sales of combustion-engine cars from 2035, something being pushed by German automakers and the European Automobile ​Manufacturers’ Association.

In an open letter to Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, campaign group ‍E-Mobility Europe and ChargeUp Europe, ​backed by nearly 200 signatories such ​as Swedish automakers Polestar and Volvo Cars, called ‍for the targets to be kept.

“We are deeply concerned about recent efforts to dilute your objectives,” the letter said, referring to intense lobbying efforts by the wider auto industry.

The groups added ‍that reopening the door to transitional technologies such as plug-in hybrids and CO2-neutral fuels would create uncertainty ‍and slow ‍the shift to electric vehicles, even ​as Chinese electric automakers streak ahead ​and ⁠cut costs.

“Every delay in Europe only ‌widens the gap with China,” it added.

The EU’s automotive package has been subject to intense lobbying, with letters from both industry and campaigners flooding Brussels ahead of the announcement.

(Reporting by Marie Mannes; Editing by ⁠Jan Harvey)
